resources.string: Coronavirus (COVID-19) is a new strain of coronavirus which may cause illness in animals or humans. In humans, several coronaviruses are known to cause respiratory infections ranging from the common cold to more severe diseases. First identified in a cluster with pneumonia symptoms in Wuhan city, Hubei province of China.

string.name: about_covid_19_symptoms
string.b: What are the symptoms of COVID-19\?

resources.string: The most common symptoms of COVID-19 are:
Coronavirus strains are spread from person to person through contaminated droplets from a person who is sick with the illness (through coughing or sneezing) or contaminated hands.
The virus can spread through touching an infected surface.

People can also catch COVID-19 if they breathe in droplets from a person with COVID-19 who coughs out or exhales droplets. This is why it is important to stay more than 1 meter (3 feet) away from a person who is sick.

string.name: treatment_for_covid_19
string.b: Is there any treatment for COVID-19\?

resources.string: The treatment of COVID-19 depends on enhancing the level of patients, treating the symptoms and easing complications, immunity as there is no specific treatment for the virus to date. Read more üåê

string.name: prevent_for_covid_19
string.b: What are the ways to prevent the disease\?

string-array.name: prevent_list
string-array.item: Washing hands with soap and water.
Maintain at least 1 metre (3 feet) distance between yourself and anyone who is coughing or sneezing.
Covering mouth and nose with your bent elbow or tissue when you cough or sneeze.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose or mouth without washing your hands.
Avoid shaking hands and just wave.
Avoid contact with animals (live or dead).
Take enough rest and take a large amount of fluids.

string.name: about_covid_19_vaccination_what
string.b: The Immune System: the Body\‚Äôs Defense Against Infection

resources.string:
To understand how COVID-19 vaccinations act, it is necessary to first understand how our bodies handle illness. When germs enter our bodies, such as the virus that causes COVID-19, they fight and multiply. This invasion, known as an infection, is what causes sickness. To combat infection, our immune system employs a number of strategies. Blood comprises both red cells, which transport oxygen to tissues and organs, and white or immunological cells, which fight illness. Different types of white blood cells fight illness in different ways:


• Macrophages are white blood cells that eat and digest germs as well as dead or dying cells. The macrophages leave behind pieces of the invading germs known as "antigens." Antigens are recognised as harmful by the body, prompting antibodies to destroy them. 

• B-lymphocytes are white blood cells that serve as a defence. They produce antibody the virus pieces left behind by the macrophages. 

• T-lymphocytes are a different type of defensive white blood cell. They infect previously affected cells in the body.


The When a person is first infected with the virus that causes COVID-19, it might take many days or weeks for their body to produce and use all of the germ-fighting tools required to overcome the infection. After the infection, the person's immune system recalls what it learnt about how to protect the body against such a disease.


TThe body stores a few T-lymphocytes known as "memory cells," which activate quickly if the body experiences the same virus again. When B-lymphocytes identify familiar antigens, they create antibodies to destroy them. Experts are still trying to figure out how long these memory cells can protect a person against the virus that causes COVID-19.

Vaccines perform in a variety of ways to provide protection. However, with all vaccines, the body is left with a supply of ‚Äúmemory‚Äù T- and B-lymphocytes that will recall how to fight that virus in the future. 

T-lymphocytes and B-lymphocytes are normally produced a few weeks after vaccination.
As a result, it is possible that a person
could become infected with the virus
that causes COVID-19 just before or
just after vaccination and then become ill as a result of the vaccine failing to give adequate protection. 

Symptoms such as fever can occur after vaccination due to the process of generating immunity. These symptoms are natural and indicate that the body is generating immunity.

string.name: about_covid_19_vaccination_types
string.b: What are the types of vaccines?

resources.string:
•Primary content and how it reacts: 
mRNA sequence that enters each cell and produces the particular virus protein 

•Function: 
The mRNA molecule is used to stimulate immunity in order for the targeted virus protein to be detected. 

•Advantages: 
Does not require any live components and is synthetically created. 
Triggers an adaptive immune response. 
Simple, easy and quick to produce. 

•Challenges: 
Its use as a vaccine during the first time in medical history. 
Some mRNA vaccines must be stored in extremely cold temperatures. 

•Vaccine candidate: 
Moderna 
Pfizer/BioNTech

•Primary content and how it reacts: 
A modified (vector) virus is used to carry the antigen genetic code. The targeted protein will be produced by the human cell. 

•Function: 
A safe viral vector is designed to transfer the targeted virus's genetic material while also activating the human immune response. 

•Advantages: 
Proven technology 
Activates an adaptive response for a more efficient immune response 

•Challenges: 
Complex producing process 
It is critical to ensure that the virus vector can be used safely. 

•Vaccine candidate: 
AstraZeneca 
CanSino Biologics 
Johnson & Johnson 
Sputnik V

•Primary content and how it reacts: 
Viruses that have been killed by extreme heat, chemicals, or radiation 

•Function: 
A virus that has been killed and is being used to boost the human immune system. 

•Advantages: 
Proven technolog 
Easy to produce 
Appropriate for those who have a weak immune system 

•Challenges: 
High producing cost 

•Vaccine candidate: 
Sinovac
